children.subject: From my experience (I work full time), you mostly just get pay increase when you're starting out but no accelerated promotion path. That being said, I read on Blind that some companies will throttle people with only a bachelor's from being promoted at some point i.e., you can't be a VP of Eng unless you have MS or higher. Pretty dumb IMO but that's the world we live in. Kinda like how these entry level roles all require a bachelor's, yet some rando high schooler who grinds Leetcode is probably equally capable of getting in
For what it's worth, lots of VPs at the company I interned at (FAANG) had only Bachelor's degrees.

I'm also only considering the 5th-year masters (not current participant). I've mostly heard from family that having an MS in CS is really beneficial with regards to being promoted faster. Of course, this is all hearsay, I'm hoping others who have experience will chime in!

history.content:
A masters in CS is a recruiting tool. It's mostly for people who didn't get a good enough job placement their senior year or are looking to transition from another STEM field into CS. The other camp of people who do the masters is those who aren't mentally ready to join the real world as working adults and want to spend another year in college as a faux undergrad. A coursework masters will not better prepare you for a SWE job if you already have 4 years of rigorous undergrad CS.  There's a reason why the MEng in EECS is filled with international students (it's the closest equivalent to the 5th year MS for external students). For a lot of people, it's just a $70k way for people to get 2-year OPT eligibility. 

The general attitude in industry is that an MS isn't really relevant. You'll get a slight bonus in starting salary (but this isn't really worth it compared to an extra year of working). A masters isn't even generally enough to start you out at a higher level (ie starting you out at Engineer 3 vs 2). Any promotions or high-regard, once you enter the company, will basically be solely based on your performance as an employee. Obviously, PhD is a whole different ball game though, since what they do at places like MSR is very different from what your average engineer working on Azure is doing.

Also, if doing a masters after you enter industry is what you're looking for, there are schools like Stanford that offer a part-time MS program specifically meant for working engineers. The upside of these programs is that your employer often will pay for it as long as you can make somewhat of a justification as to how it will make you better at your job. If you want to do back-end, you can often get some funding from your employer to take systems classes at a program like Stanford's.

The other camp of people who do the masters is those who aren't mentally ready to join the real world as working adults and want to spend another year in college as a faux undergrad. children.subject:
Nobody cares where you went to school after you have 3-5 years of work experience, as long as the school was reputable and not something like DeVry.

A part-time masters after you go into industry is used to pick up extra skills you might need on the job. You'll already be affiliated with a company and no longer need to worry about recruiting. The concerns at that point are more about which school is cheaper/has offerings that are specifically tailored to what you want to learn, not which school has better CS research rankings. A lot of companies even have university affiliates that they specifically collaborate with to provide classes that work with employee schedules.

If you're referring to leaving industry, getting a full-time MS in two years, and then coming back, I struggle to see why you would want to do that unless you're trying to pivot areas (ie trying to break into graphics or HCI). You're not going to come back with better employment prospects compared to when you left since an MS no longer opens up research-oriented roles in industry due to the PhD market already being quite saturated.

Hey Beaker, thanks for the insight, I appreciate it! Had some followup questions about doing the masters after entering industry--

When you do a masters, are you expected to do it at a school that's equally/higher ranked than Berkeley? Is it your undergrad degree or your latest schooling that is considered "where you went to school"? Because if the latter, that doesn't leave a lot of options for grad school after working in industry, so I'm wondering how people navigate that.

I think the original student answer by Beaker has a lot of good points and merits, but I think it would tend to leave undecided people feeling pretty negative about pursuing a Master's, so I'm just here to shine a light on the positives, coming from someone who was in a similar position as Anonymous Helix a year ago, then ultimately decided to pursue a Master's a year later (currently going through the application process at the moment). Just as a side note - my opinions are definitely not the truth, just my thoughts.

  • There's a lot of Master's programs out there. If you're interested, I'd recommend doing the right research to see if anything caters to your taste. This is my observation of the dichotomy of the programs based on my own preparations.
    • Professional Master's - These are more coursework heavy, 1 year programs meant to get you prepared for industry. Brashly put, it would fit what the original solution described about transitioning into CS, or giving oneself another go at a recruiting cycle with hopefully a better offer. It's also great for diving deeper into a field of interest
      • Coursework could make you more capable. In four years, let's roughly say you spent 4/8 semesters' time completing lower divs + general requirements and the other half doing CS upper divs. 2-3 upper divs per semester * 4 = 8-12 upper divs. That's really solid, especially in Berkeley's CS program. But maybe you enjoyed OS + security and want to work on systems level cybersecurity. 162 + 161 covers a lot of concepts, but it's the tip of the iceberg in terms of covering the field you're interested in. A master's program where you can take 4-6 more classes on cryptography, privacy-preserving systems, software engineering architecture design, etc. could help a lot.
      • A counter-argument to ^ - "You can learn on the job" - Yes, no doubt about that, and that definitely could be what works for some people. But with the Master's, you get to control what you study. In industry, with production pressure and deadlines, what you spend time on is heavily determined by the company's initiatives, not just your own.
    • Research focused Master's - In addition to specialized coursework, these usually 2-years (Berkeley 5th years is an exception) programs are great to dive deeper and specialize in topics that one might not have time to fully explore during undergrad, primarily through research (M.S. thesis) + coursework.
      • With this track, you will have accomplished a good amount; a lot of outcomes are ones undergrad programs usually don't have or offer - publications, close connections with professors / grad students, M.S. thesis (40-50 pages of your writing).
      • This opens doors to opportunities that a lot of undergraduate level students might not be as capable of (i.e. robotics, ML/DL, data science). Of the top of my head, if you look at a lot of AV companies, internships for working on things like onboard runtime, mapping, perception, motion planning, etc. will look for someone with M.S. and above experience, specializing in that field. Berkeley is very strong in Systems, security, AI, and ML research, but there's a lot of other fields that might pique your interest + have corresponding industry roles (i.e. PL, databases, networking, infrastructure). Like Beaker said, I agree that "research intern" roles are still largely limited to Ph.D.'s; with that said, M.S.'s opportunities > B.S.'s opportunities - the difference is not day and night, but it very much exists.
      • You get to carry out projects from the ground up. Often times, in industry, you'll be working on legacy code, so not building systems from scratch. A Master's program could be good exercise to bring a project or complicated system from ideation to tangible fruition. That experience could be really helpful to being a great engineer. The Master's of course, is not the only way to build your own projects. However, the guarantees are that you'd likely be working on something pretty involved that not any developer could do, and you'll have the mentorship of some very smart people (i.e. advising professor, other Ph.D./Masters students).
      • Test the waters for if you want to do a Ph.D. You can always go back to industry after your Ph.D., and after the Master's, if you want to put in a couple extra years, there's definitely programs that would take less time than 5-6 years b/c you have a Master's (i.e. Ph.D.'s in Europe take 3-4 years, not 5-6 like in U.S. - fully funded housing + living in the UK while working on research?? :P). This path would of course, open you up to a lot of roles that undergrads are almost never considered for.
      • To put it into perspective, 10000+'s (my guess-timate, not an official number) of CS undergrads from U.S. universities enter the market every year. On the contrary, much fewer (maybe 20000+? again just a guess) are CS graduate degree. If you just google "tech talent shortage", you'll see that there's a pretty big gap in specialized software engineering roles. A Master's could make you a pretty strong candidate.
  • "aren't mentally ready to join the real world" - Depends. I think that definitely could be true in a few cases, but I don't think it's an overwhelmingly huge camp of people.
  • "MS isn't really relevant / not enough to start at a higher level" - depends on the position. For a general front/back/full-stack engineering role - Yes. For things like AV, robotics, ML/DL, some infrastructure/network architecture roles - No. Some companies also do hire M.S. grads at a higher level (depends on the program).
  • Slight bonus - Yes. That could be an extra 20-30K. Of course, it'll take you a while (5-6 years) to make up for the 1-2 years you spent on the Master. But careers are non-linear so what you'll be doing/earning 5-6 years from now might not be your present situation (promotion? :O).
  • "mostly for people who didn't get a good enough job / transition into CS" - I agree with this except for the "mostly" part. It's hard to put a number on the split for reasons one pursue's a Master, but as mentioned above, there's more factors and outcomes than just this.

I think a better way of answering this question is focusing on not only on earnings, but also on what you want to do. 

Again, just to reiterate, I think there were a lot of strong, correct points made before, not trying to start a flame war here. I spent a good amount of time making a similar decision a year ago, so just thought I'd put down the things I considered.

If you want to make money ASAP, then by all means, a job is the way to go. However, since you've already put in so much effort to become a CS undergrad from Berkeley, you'd be a very qualified candidate for some very cool programs, and that can't be said for everybody in industry. If a program catches your eye, that could turn out to be a very fruitful experience.

Anyway, this turned out a little long, but hope it was helpful! At the end of day, it is what one makes of it, so I definitely think you can't go wrong either way!

oh and it's quite nice being able to finally apply for those jobs that say "MUST have an MS or PhD in blah blah blah" although that's mostly for AI/ML stuff. There are definitely a ton of ultra smart people with only a bachelor's but they'd just get resume-screened out for not hitting that checkbox

A significant number of EECS classes don't hire 10-hour TAs for this specific reason. Can you let us know what EECS class allows for 10-hour MS TAs (in substantial numbers)? I feel like if there really is a class that takes on 10 hr MS TAs, doing the MS might actually make you better off.

A lot of my friends who decided to do the 5th year had to quit teaching because the department was trying to strongarm them into teaching 20 hours to get their money's worth out of full tuition remission. The department is only receptive to 10-hour TAs if you're a PhD student. PhD students are different because teaching is part of their graduation requirements and they're paid from department funds either way. But the department is really really stingy about paying MS student tuition usually.

Also, as I mentioned in my above comment, "MUST have a MS or PhD" roles almost always end up going to PhDs. It's not about being ultra smart. It's about needing to hire a researcher. A PhD trains people to be good researchers and so does a research-based MS, but an industry-oriented 5th year MS or MEng is not what they're looking for. For R&D lab jobs, they're going to ask you about publications and conferences you've presented at, so if your background isn't heavy in research, you're not going to have a lot to talk about at your interview. You can technically have the paper qualifications, but you're still not going to be prepared for the nature of the job.

Well, the class I teach doesn't have a "substantial" number of 10-hour MS TA's. There are just 2 including me. I'm very surprised to hear about this this actually. The class I teach has consistently had two to three 10-hour MS TA's every semester for as long as I can remember (I've been teaching for 8 semesters), so I never thought twice about relying on TA'ing to fund my tuition.

I can't tell if you're an undergrad from your responses in this thread so far, but if you are, I don't think you should let this psuedo department policy deter you. I imagine if you have a good relationship with at least one professor he/she would let you do a 10-hour. If my friend and I can do a 10-hour position during a cash-strapped COVID semester I am sure they have even more positions available during a normal semester.

I'm also pretty surprised to her about your view on the MS/PhD thing. I had a pretty tough time recruiting for these roles as an undergrad despite the fact that I did most of my research in undergrad, but my yield rate in getting AI/ML interviews suddenly skyrocketed once I got into the MS program despite having mostly the same qualifications as before. I do agree that being a researcher instead of a coding whiz is what they're looking for--by ultra smart people with only a bachelor's I was referring to undergrads with first-author conference papers, not just Leetcode wizards haha. Again, not sure what your background is, so apologies if it sounds like I'm condescending. Unless you already have an MS and are working in a research role that you feel woefully underprepared for, I don't think you should let these misconceptions deter you from applying :) I think the thesis requirement does make you into a stronger researcher / engineer, even if it's not as rigorous as a PhD. And at least among the PhD's I know, many of them have no interest in leaving academia so I imagine the competition for an industry MS/PhD position is... well, mostly MS haha (that, plus the fact that the number of PhD's in the USA is already very low)

I should also mention that I'm not an anomalous MS student who happens to be more research-heavy. In fact, many of the other MS students' projects I've seen are way more complicated / legit than mine, and they have even more success than I do at landing those specialized industry research roles. I'm under the impression that Stanford's program is the "true" industry-oriented program since they only take classes over there. But over here, everyone is required to do an independent research project and write up a thesis, just like any PhD student would do.
^That being said, I totally agree with you that the MS is pretty useless for a standard SWE job lol. The company I currently work at doesn't even offer the tiny pay bump for the extra degree

Can I get a specific class? For my own use LOL. I just finished my BS this semester so I'm probably a year below. I used to teach one of the sixteens and was told by a head GSI that they weren't gonna be able to keep me on as a 10 hour if I went MS (it was part of the reason I didn't go 4th year MS actually). It can tell you from my own experience that this isn't just hearsay. It happened to a couple of my friends for classes like 70 too.

My own background is digital circuits/embedded (so the furthest thing in CS from AI/ML). Maybe it's a cultural difference within CS, but when people in architecture say MS/PhD, they don't want some fresh-faced 22 y/o kid with a 5th year masters. They're usually looking for a specialized engineer who knows how to work on a specific research problem and has done multiple industry graduate internships (these are common in architecture). As an example, I personally interviewed at a household name company for a listed MS/PhD role (a referral from someone I worked with) and was told that 80% of the people in that role had PhDs. Needless to say, I did not get the job.
+1 interested in the class as well! I TA for one of the upper div courses, and was hoping to continue during a potential 5th year MS as well.

FYI you basically pay nothing for the Master's if you TA and you're in-state. In fact, depending on how the COVID stuff goes, you might just pay $800 per semester with no exorbitant housing costs. I'm actually working full time while doing the Master's and a 10-hour TA position, and it's a pretty sweet deal economically. Plus you extend the time window during which you can apply for new grad roles, which might be pretty important if COVID continues to screw around with new grad job prospects.

history.content:
hi! I've looked through some past threads on this so I'll try to ask some more specific/unique questions but I was hoping someone could give me some advice based on my situation. about me:

- don't intend to do a PhD or anything, I want to stay in industry long-term

- I'm an L&S CS junior with ~3.7 GPA, a little behind on my degree because I was taking reduced course load for a while (I'll have 3 CS UDs done by end of sp21) and I've never done research in college

- I interned at a company last summer (after sophomore year) and will likely be returning this summer. to be honest, I've had subpar success recruiting and COVID definitely hasn't helped-- I can see myself working at this company full-time for a couple of years but not really long-term. I'm working on my skills and I will definitely be recruiting for other new grad jobs, but success on finding a good competing offer is up in the air (the company I'm at rn is pretty good about converting interns to FT)

I've recently been considering the 5th year masters, for no particular reason right now but just gathering some information. some questions I have are:

- for those of you who are doing your 5th year masters with the intent of eventually joining industry-- why? what led you to your decision?

- my family suggested that I recruit for full-time, but keep the option of doing a masters open, and if I don't find a full-time job that I'm excited to do, spend the next year working on the masters and then try again for industry after that. thoughts on how this would work out? (I will likely have a job that I won't mind starting out with through a return offer, but am hoping to find something better). 

- I understand that a masters degree doesn't have much profit income-wise for entry level in industry, but does it help as you go higher? can it help you get promoted faster and/or be a more-highly regarded employee? if so, what are the benefits? asking this because the whole process of looking for and doing undergraduate research seems a little daunting and time-consuming, and I'm looking for opinions on if it would be worth it or if in hindsight my time would've been better spent preparing for industry and just aiming to get a better job immediately after undergrad. it's just kinda difficult because it seems neither option (doing undergrad research or upping my industry skills) has a guarantee of success proportional to the effort I'd put in... I just don't know what to do.

- how should I begin choosing a research area? I really don't know what I'm interested in; thus far I've just been aiming to work as a SDE in back-end and I don't even have many UDs under my belt. where should I start?

also, if I start in industry and decide to do a masters later while working-- I'm pretty much limited to doing an online degree, which berkeley doesn't offer, right? 

I know some of these questions are kinda subjective so if nothing else I'd really appreciate hearing from people who are doing or looking to do a 5th year masters and joining industry after that what their thinking is, because I'm kinda lost. thanks in advance!
history.subject: if the final goal is industry, how do you decide about getting a masters or not?
